subsc: Central government administration,Agricultural extension and research,Forestry

abstracts.cdata!:
Because the project's development
            objectives are not met and the investments are unlikely to
            be sustainable, project outcome is assessed as
            unsatisfactory. Lessons learned are the following: Private
            sector involvement through leasing arrangements, was to have
            been an important project vehicle for improving the
            efficiency of plantation management. However, at appraisal
            the government sought to maintain the status quo and argued
            that leasing was not an option, with the result that no
            improvements in efficiency or in the financial viability of
            industrial plantations were likely. 2) The failure to engage
            the primary stakeholders in the timber industry during
            implementation was one of the project's more
            significant failings. 3) Steps leading to substantive
            institutional and legal reform should have been clearly
            articulated earlier, rather than in the final year of
            project implementation. 4) A well focused and purposeful
            training program, extended to diverse groups of staff, made
            a significant contribution to improve technical operations
            and management, but these improvements needed an apt
            enabling institutional, legal, and policy framework. 5)
            Placing task management responsibilities in the Resident
            Mission posed additional challenges; regular oversight may
            result in less frequent "formal" supervision
            reporting, and an over-optimistic assessment of project
            progress. Issues concerning governance, institutional
            sustainability, and expenditure management must be addressed more.
